title: David de Gea tells friends he could start for Man Utd against Liverpool
text:
The Spanish shot-stopper will find out the results of his scan on Friday (Picture: Getty)

While Manchester United appeared to rule David de Gea out of Sunday’s clash with Liverpool, the goalkeeper himself reportedly still believes he has a chance of playing.

The 28-year-old suffered a groin injury while playing for Spain earlier in the week and had to be replaced after an hour during the side’s Euro 2020 qualifier against Sweden.

Manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said De Gea was unlikely to play any part against Liverpool, but, according to The Times, the shot-stopper is hopeful of being involved.

De Gea was replaced by Chelsea’s Kepa in the 1-1 draw with Sweden (Picture: Getty)

The injury is not thought to be particularly serious and De Gea has told friends that he could start, with a final decision only being made after further tests on Friday.

However, United’s medical staff are rather more pessimistic about the Spaniard’s chances of playing and Sergio Romero is still widely expected to start.

‘David needs a scan,’ Solskjaer told Sky Sports the day after De Gea picked up the groin problem.

‘I think he’ll be out. It certainly looked like it anyway judging on last night so it’s just one of those things.’

Incredibly, Romero has not started a league match in 17 months, though is widely considered one of the best No.2s in the Premier League.

Sergio Romero has always been reliable when called upon by United (Picture: Getty)

While De Gea still hopes to play, midfielder Paul Pogba will not be involved, with Solskjaer saying: ‘Paul had an injury, he came back, he worked really hard.

‘He came back and played a couple of games, maybe played through the pain barrier.

‘He had a scan after the Arsenal game and maybe needed a few weeks’ rest in a boot so hopefully he won’t be too long, but he won’t make this game, no.’
